I've had the regular margarita several times in the past, always strong and not too sweet. We tried drinking for a little while and only ended up taking a few sips, they were so sweet. We even had our other friend try it and she said she liked it, which means they weren't strong at all (she doesn't like the taste of tequila).
I take the drinks back to the bar and when I ask the bartender to please re-make them, she gives me even more attitude, telling me that there are 5 shots of tequila in each one and pointed at the glass to show me that the tequila was roughly 2/3 of the drink. I calmly say okay and ask her for my money back, since she's obviously trying to argue that the margaritas are strong.
Finally she hands me back the cash and walks away, as I'm counting I realize that she only gave me back $24 instead of $32. I wait and flag her down again and again calmly ask her for the correct change. Again she gives me attitude and proceeds to tell me that they were $12 each, I finally give her some attitude back and tell her "No, they were the ones with Cazadores". 
I'm thinking this ordeal is almost coming to close, when she decides to insult us after she hands me the correct change. As she's walking away from me, she says "Those drinks were strong, you guys are crazy".
That was the last straw and the reason that I have written this review. Nothing my friends or I did warranted the level of attitude and rudeness that the bartender gave to us.
author: Anica S.

description:
Went to LAC for the first time last Saturday night around 12:30 and then ended up here again on Monday afternoon for a coworker's birthday happy hour, so I've had an interesting contrast of experiences at this place in the past week.

Saturday night was super crowded (even ran into a college classmate, and I went to school 2800 miles away!), almost to the point of being painful, but luckily I weaseled my way to the bar early for a stiff marg that made the masses more tolerable.  

Monday started out fairly super slow -- I think there were only 3 other people in there when my friends and I arrived around 7 -- but it definitely picked up more as the night went on.  Friendly bartender.

at $9 the margaritas aren't the cheapest drink on the block (and I would argue they're maybe a little too generous with their ice) but overall they definitely get the job done.  After the two I had each night I was certainly in a good place.  Big drinks -- pint glass size.  

I shudder to think about what my hangovers would have been like if I hadn't followed my visits both times with late night trips to El Farolito for a burrito the size of my forearm.

Fun, kitschy, quintessentially mission decor (faded pinatas, a large fat head of a gerbil looking thing, etc).  Bathroom is not the greatest, but it's about what I'd expect for a 22nd Street dive.  

Minus one star for being cash only (but there is an ATM directly next door outside the laundromat) and for being almost uncomfortably packed (/ subpar bartender/patron ratio) on weekend night.  Overall definitely fun nights out here.
author: Molly B.

description: I didn't know they we're cash only so I couldn't tip. The refused to take my order for the rest of the night and gave my friends a bad time even though they we're tipping. The drinks weren't even that good. This is a classless establishment.
author: Wesley L.

description: I ordered a Moscow Mule - $8 - and watched the bartender fill a tall glass of ice at least 90% full with vodka, then add a splash of ginger beer and squeeze in half a lime. It was SO strong. Boyfriend had a gin & tonic that was also about a 9:1 ratio. Yay for strong, cheap drinks! It's also a pretty cute space, but it was way too hot without AC that day.
author: Rachel M.

description:
What do you get when you combine Dia del Muerte decor, ennui and fashion as only hipsters can do it, and mostly tequila margaritas? Latin American Club. 

Can be crowded, is cash only, and you have to endure the vneck bedecked denizens of the mission but people... eight. dollar. margaritas. And not yucky premixed sugar-filled margaritas. Fresh-squeezed lime and mostly tequila (I think there's triple sec for good measure) eight dollar margaritas.

Get here. Get two (or three). Get weird.
author: marissa l.

description:
My go to spot - great margaritas, as long as they're not made by the older gentleman, bald head, a little on the heavy side -

Theres a guy who looks very dapper with his slacks, button up, and vest - he makes the best margarita!

Ive come here so many times I've lost count, great memories with my friends, Latin American Club... i love you
author: Mario M.

description:
$9 margaritas in a tall glass with 75-80% tequila - I'm in (or so I am in the moment) ! If you need something to help you get to the same level as your more buzzed/drunk friends, this is the drink to get. The well margarita uses El Jimador Tequila, just FYI.

Decor: Pinatas hanging from the ceiling, enough said.

Handy Tip: CASH ONLY - make sure you come prepared!
author: Melissa L.

description: This is quite the place indeed. They must save money on bar staff, because the drinks are so strong you only order a few. There's something about watching the bartender mix the margaritas, and by mix I mean upending a bottle of tequila. I'm actually more of a fan of the long island iced teas they have here. Still very alcoholic, but they go down a little easier.  They didn't even threaten to kick us out until after we broke our fifth glass accidentally, watch where you swing those  drunken arms. My shoes have still not recovered from someone spilling a melted candle all over them. The 3 times I've been here have always been enjoyable, and followed by a painful headache. I wish it wasn't cash only but as their POS system as a large bowl I don't see that happening anytime soon. 5/5 would LAC
author: David B.

description: I will have to agree with those who have been posting reviews about this bar, it's very good and one of the best options in the Mission area. Although the club itself has nothing special what keeps me coming back are the $4 or $5 drinks. I have met very interesting people a few of them have become really good friends of mine. The bartenders do a great job, during the weekends they barely talk to the guests, they simply stay busy making drinks and getting them fast. I can't recall when was the last time that I had to wait more than 30 seconds to get my drink. The decoration of this bar is also very artistic, it gives the bar a touch of bohemian look.
author: Jessica R.

description:
This is a very festive bar in the Mission with lots of Piñatas and knickknacks. 

They make strong Margaritas, too strong for some people.

I had an event here and everyone seemed to have a good enough time but in my opinion the bartenders weren't very friendly,

I brought around forty people and they didn't seem like they could care less about the extra business, they didn't send me one round.
author: Manny F.

description:
I used to loooove coming here.  So many nights, I'd drag coworkers or friends here to have "a quick drink" "before dinner,"... only to exit hours later starving but unable to stomach the idea of actually eating, intoxicated with no real memory of what I'd ordered (--probably-- just a few margaritas), and a fuzzy but steadily growing sense of shame over what had transpired in the last few hours.   As others have mentioned, their margaritas are STRONG. 

The last time I stopped by here... it looked like the place had been cleaned up?!  I mean, there were still pinatas and weird crap on the walls, but everything else seemed kind of... remodeled. Not so divey now.  Boooo..
author: Heidi M.

description:
John, my favorite bartender in SF is here on Saturdays. He makes the strongest and most delicious drinks. He's the reason I keep coming back. 
Drinks are good and strong! When in doubt, get the margarita!
author: Nilu r.

description:
Came in on Friday May 25th, 2012 - around 11 PM. Ordered the pint of margarita like others recommended for $9 (others quoted $8) - well grabbed 2 - but gave a $20 and got $2 change instead of $4. Overall this drink is absolutely as mentioned - a pint glass of tequila and an absolute great value.

Bar had a good ratio for a Friday Night - not the typical Marina crowd; multiple bathroom as others mentioned and the service was on point. Only downfall was cash only and the bottle neck near the bar - but I will definitely be back in the area.
author: Brian D.

description:
Still 5 stars. This time I actually saw them pour the margaritas. It's not 3/4 alcohol, it's almost ENTIRELY alcohol. The 5 stars are for the value, which trumps the fact that there is always a line for the bathroom and nowhere to sit.

I was also stoked to see Davis' Sudwerk kegs sitting around. Good stuff!
author: Andrew L.

description: Don't come here on the weekends.  It's too damned crowded.
author: Logan P.

description:
I've been here a few times and I've always left regretting it. Is that a good or bad thing? I don't really know.

You've probably heard that the margaritas are worth it, well, it's true. They're cheap for the large glass you get, but you'll be sitting there trying to chug it down as you mingle with your friends. Also, you'll probably feel horrible in the morning, even though you've only had one of them. Maybe I should just sleep it off, you say? Doesn't work. I felt slow and incompetent the next day, so I'm glad I went on a Friday.

It's really loud and dark inside. Usually, you'll wait around to find a seat. It's never too packed in here, so there's always some room to stand around the bar. The pinatas hanging on the ceiling give it a nice touch, but it's so dark, you really can't see much. I wonder what it looks like during the day.

The bartenders seemed nice, but I rarely even talked to them since I was out for a birthday. It's also nice that a mariachi player walks in to ask for money and play for you.
author: Andrew T.

description: Myself and one other person entered the Latin American Club at 1:00 AM and sat at a booth. At 1:30 AM the 2 staff members and myself and my friend were the only four people in the lounge area. My friend and I left at 1:30 AM due to closing time, the wallet fell under the booth table we were sitting at and we left without noticing. I went straight home and in the morning noticed my wallet was lost. The Latin American does not have a working telephone number and does not open until 6pm. When I came back to ask, the bartender was drinking with patrons and did not ask my name or for my contact information. The bartender that was on staff looked in the register and walked upstairs, said he found nothing and went back to drinking, when I tried to ask who was working the night before he became hostile. I will be pursuing proper management details to investigate the employees that were encountered and I hope that SFPD will be able to contact me with any information in regards to the business in question any possibilities that leads to the return of my identification cards and possessions as soon as possible.
author: Roxanne P.

description: Looking for a fantastic bar on a Saturday afternoon??? The Latin American Club is not the place for you and your friends, especially if you are a group of women! As a city native who came here with 5 other city natives, married to city natives, my friends and I couldn't be more insulted by the incredibly rude service we received. Mr. Poser, the bald bartender, immediately judged us the minute we walked in by saying "are you all ordering margaritas so I can knock them all out at one time?" Hmmm, a little judgmental? I'm gonna guess that Mr. Baldy would be furious if anyone in our group made judgements toward him or his friends...so I won't, nor will my friends. Enjoy sitting there eating your lunch at a table with patrons who are clearly your friends. You have time for that because you now have approximately five patrons now that we're leaving. This clearly is a bar only welcoming of people they know. You should broaden your horizons because there are fantastic natives, transplants, etc. you are not giving yourself the opportunity to know. By the way, clean the bathroom...it's disgusting.
author: Antoinette H.

description:
3.5 stars. 

good drinks (but the margaritas across the street are better). 

One of my favorite doormen in the city. (one star for that alone). Totally on his game while remaining chill and accommodating. 

love the pinatas. and that sign about how to treat alcoholism (is it available for purchase?) 

But this place gets wicked HOT! Yeah, it's kinda wall-to-wall, and yes, it's San Francisco, but you guys gotta spring for some fans or crank the A/C. I'd be willing to subsidize it with an extra .50 on every drink or something! 

And just a side note, there seem to be better looking guys here than at some of the places nearby. Not sure why or why we all noticed that, but just an FYI to the prowling ladies of yelp.
author: Mike V.

description: A wise man once said that no matter what time of the night you go to LAC it should be the last bar you go to. When you watch them pour five shots of tequila into a pint glass and top it off with a splash of triple sec and lime juice it isn't hard to see why. They don't taste great, but they are extremely efficient. It is also the only reason to go here. I see people ordering beer and I just ask myself "Why?"
author: Michael S.

description: I guess I was already too buzzed to notice how much tequila was in the margarita I pretty much pounded. I know it tasted good. I know my friend suggested we go there for that specifically. I also know that was the 2nd time in 2 hours I'd been there. On my previous visit, it was bulleit rye and sour beer, which I found to be an amazing combo. sweet & sour perfection. The bartender was cool, the music was good, and there are these really delicious cheap latin hot dogs next door at Los Shucos. What else do you need, man?!!
author: Caddy M.

description:
Take a Southwestern style bar and drop it into the Mission and what do you  get?  This joint.  It is a total hipster version of a Southwestern themed Mexican bar.  By "southwestern" I don't mean cowboy hats and steers but sombreros and piñatas.  

Came here last night to hang with my boyfriend's "crew" as he calls them.  I was the only chic and they hadn't really spoken much with me, so I got to be the center of attention.  Little is better for the ego the unfaltering attention of three guys.  They were super nice, getting me drinks and listening to my ridiculous stories and telling funny, embarrassing anecdotes about Jesse.  

The selling point for this place is definitely their chocolate beers!  Whoever had the idea of mixing beer and chocolate should get some kind of award for increasing the level of the world's happiness. This place has really authentic feeling semi-hipster, semi-divey feel.  It really should be better known!
author: Nikki K.

description:
Caution, Caution, Caution! 

3 hours of sleep Friday night + work all day Saturday + margaritas from the Latin American Club+ 4 hours of sleep + work again all day Sunday= one long and fun weekend filled with no sleep! 

The margaritas here are no joke. I had heard all about them from my room mate Tiffany Y. and had to try them. Well needless to say we had a pretty good night. 

The vibe here is way cool. They have pinatas hanging from the ceiling and random pictures of dogs on the wall. Good crowd of people. I am sure to be back for more of those margaritas.Yum!!
author: Danielle K.

description:
The Latin American Club needs help FAST in 2 area: 

1) Decor (WTF is going on in this place? Is that someone's bed sheet hanging against that back wall? And if you're going to hang pinatas, can I at least get a crack at one? I mean really!)

2) Nomenclature (The Latin American Club? Represented by a horseshoe? Am I missing something?)

The Latin American Club ROCKS in these 2 areas:

1) Did you just give me a fifth of tequila for $8 bucks? Because there is no way in h*ll that you can ACTUALLY call this thing in my hand a margarita. This is pure tequila...maybe with a splash of lime.

2) Bouncer friend: Thank you for making me psuedo bouncer last night and letting me invade your bubble. I greatly enjoyed pretending to run the show while you chatted with some customers at the tables outside. 

Final Thoughts:

It was fun....but that can be attributed to my company rather than this establishment. Nothing stands out (other than the neon horseshoe outside) but that can be a positive or a negative. Thanks for a good night! Perhaps I'll venture back!
author: Annalise F.

description:
If you have any intention of remembering your name and/or who you left with, do NOT order anything that involves hard liquor.  Go with a beer.  Those margaritas were poised to knock me full out on my ass, even after I asked for more sweet and sour.  You don't need roofies with those drinks, just make sure he/she finishes it.  You also might want to make sure a vomit receptacle is nearby for later, because it most likely will happen.

Not a bad place, I like the overall decor.  I am a big fan of the pinatas on the ceiling- especially the power ranger one.  We didn't stay long so I didn't get a chance to scope this place out as much as I would have liked, but it's definitely a place I can see coming back to.

-1 star for trying to eviscerate my liver with one drink 
-1 star for not having straws for said drink.  Who doesn't have straws?
author: Pam S.

description:
The margaritas here are so deceptively strong that I feel like I'm back in college in New Orleans walking down Bourbon Street with a tall hand grenade.

And you know what? Sometimes I want to get that drunk.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
I like any place with 10+ year old Power Ranger pinatas hanging from the ceiling.

I also like any place with $8 margaritas that get you REALLY drunk.

This place is a scene, but its fun, we like to bring out of town guests here.  Nothing special about the drinks (aside from the strength), decent beer selection, average prices.
author: Kristin P.

description:
Last night I went to Latin America Club.  This morning I'm recovering from Latin America Club's margarita (notice how it's singular).

Super strong drinks for cheap.  What else is there to say?
author: Jane N.

description:
I was afraid this might happen.
 
I found myself at the Latin American Club incredibly lit at midnight on the evening before I had to get up at 5:30a to catch my flight home. I drunkenly consoled myself with their signature margaritas and telling myself: "Of course I must stay out! It's my last night in SF, and I must collect as many experiences as possible before I leave!" (Yeah, 3.5 days in SF and I started saying things like "collect experiences.")
 
I think the famous margarita tasted good, though I'm really not sure. At that point, I could have drunk pure gasoline and not blinked an eye (in fact, I think I did at The Attic earlier that day).
 
I did enjoy the giant dog portraits (a Chinese Crested and a Chihuahua, if I recall correctly) and the Vaquero named Jacob who wandered in to hand out serenades for cash. We asked for something upbeat and he delivered a nice little number and showed off his angelic voice.
 
The boys who's table we crashed seemed nice enough and just returned from a trip to Tucson, oddly enough. This bar came as a recommendation from the bartender at Bliss Bar, whom warned us about their margaritas...which, now that I think about it, I walked right out of that bar and down Valencia with in my hand. Oh, dear...
 
Other than that, I can't say I recall much of the place. I got a little too preoccupied collecting experiences and the details are kind of fuzzy.
author: Lauren V.

description:
Best Cocktail: Old Fashioned 
Order them from John!

This place is all around great, but the best part is how well they make 
their cocktails and how strong they are! I only ordered one drink while I was there, an OLD FASHIONED and it was fabulous! If you want a great Old Fashioned come here and order them from John! He makes them strong and delicious!
author: Aaron B.

description: Strong drinks and reasonable prices. The decor is decidedly interesting in a dive-bar sort of way. If you like dives but dislike rough and smelly crowds, this place is a good bet. The bathrooms are even clean!
author: Christopher L.

description: Went here for a bit of a day drinking spot, and the margarita is definitely as strong as you can get it (I didn't even order it, but Joe did, and can definitely attest to it).  I opted for the prosecco, which was just as tasty (although not as potent).  You gotta love the random decor of this place: dolls and random knick-knacks all over the place, and the tables and chairs are nothing special.  I was also wondering how long some of those pinatas have been up on the ceiling for.  It all adds to the charm of the Latin American Club.  I can see how later at night, this may have been a bit of a packed place, but for a happy hour/later afternoon drink, it's a winner.
author: Mel G.

description:
Exactly what you would expect in the Mission and then some more tequila.  A fun bar with some of the most dangerous margarita's I've found: literally a pint glass 5/6ths filled with tequila, a fresh lime, and some triple sec.  Not necessarily the tastiest margarita I've had, but definitely memorable and effective.  I'm a big fan of the decor at Latin American Club, especially the large mouse painting/mural.  Whimsical trinkets adorn the walls and piñatas hang from the ceiling, providing many interesting points of conversation. 

The one negative thing about this bar has to be bartenders.  I've been several times and each bartender I've met has served up sass with the drinks. Not really the most hospitable, but as long as they are still making that margarita I'll be back.
author: David P.

description:
Bar was festively decorated and service was fast. 

At closing time the staff became incredibly rude and used threatening tones to kick people out. Considering I was sober, I felt that it was unnecessarily hostile and I wouldn't come back here again.
author: Craig H.

description:
Vodka Tonic - $4 - in case you want your quinine antimalarial to go with the Latin vibe.  Tasty, they use good tonic water.
Margarita - $7 - you've heard what the other folks here have said about the margaritas.  It comes in a pint glass.

Most recommended though:
Mojito - $8 - comparatively more expensive, but with good reason.  They make these right here-- fresh peppermint, muddled with syrup,  good lime juice squeezed on the spot, plenty of rum, and a bit of soda water.  

Bar is kind of small, not much seating.  Other than that, this place is grand!  Not entirely your typical mission crowd either, a good blend of folks.
author: Kes D.

description: The infamous margaritas... piece of advice - don't watch how it is made because you'll have trouble stomaching the ratio of alcohol to syrup in the drink. Finishing that drink is also the last thing I remember that night and the first thing I remembered in the morning. Proceed with caution!
author: Jennifer Z.

description: Fun atmosphere. I really enjoyed the piñatas on the ceiling. I was told by a hipster sitting next to me that the margaritas were the best items on the menu. Completely agree. The margaritas are worth the trip.
author: Arian R.

description: this isn't necessarily a bad thing because maybe i should have loaded up on carbs before drinking one, but the margaritas are STRONG. i had one and i was OUT. i love the bartender. she was totally cool. we were in the mood for piña coladas, which they don't make, but she had a few suggestions throughout sf and the east bay for us to try.
author: Mae I.

description:
I don't remember much about this place except:

1. The margaritas are STRONG! I had two sips, and was DONE for the night. (Granted, I might have downed a few cocktails during dinner at Luna Park, but my memory cannot confirm this.)

2.  My shock when the tamale lady showed up INSIDE the bar at 2am in the morning. My even greater shock when I discovered that a single tamale costs $5! (Not shocked enough to convince my friend to buy me a tamale, however.)

3. The "doorman" that opens the door for you might actually be a homeless man. If he is a homeless man, you're better off not asking him for advice on "where's the best pizza around here", as he may tell you to "look it up on the tiny computer in your hands" (also known as your cellphone).
author: Elaine C.

description:
Great dive bar but can get a little crowded during peak hours.  Best place for a first date at around 6pm, or late night shenanigans after midnight to finish off.  Bartenders are chill and quick to serve.

Pro Tip:  Best viewing angle is back up against the opposite wall of the bar.  Usually, you can stand there with one other friend, and check people out.

Bon Chance
author: Nick H.

description:
If you were to poll Joe the Plumber, Joe Six-pack and any other "Joe" character that gets a chuckle while defining an entire cross-section of working America... I'd be willing to bet they'd feel comfortable throwing back a few stiff cocktails at LAC. This kind of dive bar is just my speed -
 dark, divey, and utterly inexpensive. $8 double-margaritas will have you staring at their art-adorned walls and and Scooby Doo piñatas in no time.

This is the second time I've had a chance to drink here... and it's quickly becoming one of my favorite spots in the city.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
This place should be called Latin American Decoration Club. I came here for the first time last month and was blown away by the hanging pinatas and other attempts to spice up the establishment.

Aside from the tacky decor, I was into their philosophy--zero to shwastey in 16oz. For $8 you get a pint of tequila cleverly disguised as a "margarita." The bartenders were responsive and competent from what I could tell. What more could you ask for?

Excellent place to pregame. Not sure I'd stay here for an entire night. I made the mistake of coming here for a nightcap on an evening that already saw me at my worst. Needless to say, ordering their "margarita" at 1am was not the last mistake I made that night. 

Have fun, but you've been warned.
author: Max S.

description:
strong strong margaritas. it will get you off to a great start for the night if you plan on going all out! :)

interesting decor, definitely lots to look at with the pinatas hanging from the ceiling and random pieces/junk behind the bar.

good place to go for a quick drink if you're waiting for a table at a restaurant close by.  would not go out of my way to get a drink here.
author: Melody T.

description:
I love this bar, but not for the margaritas as everyone claims are the best around. I have found that if you order with salt, be prepared to down a big swig of salt water at the end of your drink. Much better without salt, but honestly there are better margaritas to be had.

The beer selection and other drink specials are A+ and the vibe here is fun, loud and laid back (can you be all 3? yes!). Just dont show up expecting the best margarita ever, and you'll leave happy.
author: Mike M.

description:
Another nice Mission bar to casually meander into in the wee hours of the night. On a weekend night you can expect this place to be packed and smelling like a barn, but any other night it is usually pretty chill. 

Last time I went here me and my friend decided it would be a good idea to stand around talking about awkward things until a table became readily available. Somewhere between discussing Bacon Bra (Google it people!) and bot flies a group of people scurried out of the bar and we made ourselves comfortable. Lesson: Make sure you have enough horrendous stories gathered to clear the nearest table.

The drink I sipped was strong, but that doesn't really mean much when you only drink beer (IPA is the WAY).

The decor, as so many people have raved about, is amazing. Think if Michel Gondry and David Lynch had a baby together, and then that baby had a nightmare. This is what it would look like, people. 

Disheveled drunkards, peeling pinatas, a wall of dusty cuckoo clocks, and lets not forget that creepy nurse mannequin that looks like it's straight out of Silent Hill.

Love this place.
author: Samantha P.

description:
I like Latin American Club, I've been there a few times and the only negative thing I could say about it was that it was too crowded.
 
Went there last night with a friend from out of town to treat him to their famous margarita, along with 2 other friends. We ordered the drinks, $24, and I counted out the bills: 3 5's and 9 1's.
 
I handed the stack of bills to the bartender, a 30-something brunette, who I would later learn was pissed off at the world. She walked to the other side of the bar, then came back a minute later and threw the 9 1's on the bar in front of me. "You gave me 9 1's", she said matter-of-factly.
 
"...Well, I also gave you 3 5's" I said, confused. She immediately escalated the conversation to a ridiculous level of intensity, saying that she counted the money immediately after receiving it and that I was accusing her of stealing. I asked if she could maybe look around the bar to see if she had set them down by mistake, but she just got more agressive at the suggestion.
 
Eventually I said fuck it and started to pay her...again...adding another 20 to the stack of 1's. She refused to take the money, took our drinks back and told us to leave.
 
So all told, my 3 friends and I got a sip each of our drinks in exchange my $15 that somehow "disappeared". We also got some truly truly awful service.
 
I honestly can't believe that this bartender could fail so hard at basic transactions and customer communication, and I'm more and more convinced that I was robbed by her. I don't plan on coming back.
author: John S.

description:
I've gone twice and each time it was the same. "Hilariously" decorated with a bunch of crazy crap hanging from the roof. Dark and oppressive atmosphere. And not in a good way (like noc noc), I mean "reminds you of death and dying". People frantically flirting with each other around plastic tables. 

Damn strong margaritas though! Bartenders are nice too.
author: Hans A.

description:
I've only been here once, due to my avoidance (for no other reason than my laziness) of the mission. This place definitely left a lasting impression, and I can't wait to get back.

Met some friends here, they already had a table, so that was a plus right off the bat. I'd heard about the famous margaritas at this place, so I went for it. Cheap, large, and VERY strong. Plus plus. Loved the funky decor - the pinatas hanging from the ceiling just made me smile. Plus plus plus. Finally, I think my favorite part of the whole place is the fact that it is local enough, small enough, laid back enough, and chill enough that people actually bring their pets with them. LOVED the dogs that were there to join in the drink and be merry action. Plus plus plus plus. 

4 pluses for LAC = 4 stars on Yelp. Maybe next time I'll go for a second margarita, which I'm sure would turn this into a 5 star review!
author: Krista S.

description:
Not only are we Latin people romantic but we are also givers! That is why the rum/tequila/vodka whatever it is you are given, it comes filled with passion and a lot of it! So don't get too passionate with the margaritas or else you might end up passed out somewhere! 

Great spot! Packed on weekends but worth the experience!
author: Marcela R.

description:
It was early evening and I had a 'Ricky Martin' inspired moment. Crazy Margarita Latin night!

There were a few girls we met that wanted to do something different so what the heck, right? One girl recommended the Latin Club. The name sounded perfect so we said we would see them there and off we went.

So standing outside I was trying to figure out if I was in the right place. What the hell is with a giant horseshoe and Latin American? Inside it got insanely worse. I guess if you get drunk enough you don't mind the cheap seating and really sad decorations. It was like someone went to a party store with $100 to decorate the club.

To ensure you are drunk enough, the bartenders are pouring giant margaritas. While some of our local yelpers will be happy to know another place to get a big strong drink on the cheap, I prefer a bit more quality to my booze. Maybe even something that tastes like a margarita and not iced tequila with a lime slice.

The club wasn't exactly hopping. There were a few big groups of people and smaller parties but it didn't have a normal club vibe. Maybe it was just too damn dark in there that people didn't feel safe walking around. Or they might just be scared of that weird rat decoration.

Not worth a return trip unless you love a good dive.
author: Nick B.

description: What's not to like? Big, super-strong, tasty margaritas, a bartender who didn't mind our chowing down on Papalote burritos at the bar and who then kindly offered to toss our trash, and some tables to sit at if you're lucky enough to grab one.
author: Pamela S.

description:
As a card carrying Mexican, I cannot help but love any place that has pinatas as a part of their decor. It takes all I have inside me, quite frankly, to keep from finding the bar's broom handle and beating the shit out of one or all of the ten or so pinatas hanging from the ceiling.

The margaritas will put you on your rear. They are strong, tasty and will throw you around the way you like it. 

Drink too many, however, and you'll end up crawling on the floor. 

Side note: They need to provide straws...what do they have against them?
author: Jay H.

description:
Me (after ordering a drink): Hey, can I please have a straw?
Bartender: Um. We actually don't have straws here.

Just then the cutest black-white speckled mutt named Zero trotted by me to make his way through the crowd.

I love this place(!)
author: Meredith R.

description:
holy fekc. the margaritas. served in a pint glass and guaranteed to wreck you.

this is a short review cuz i don't remember much.

totes coming back when i'm in town.
author: Son V.

description:
Oh man, so sad to write this review as I've been coming here for 12 years.  After last nights treatment by bartender and additional staff I will not be returning here ever again, which sucks.  The place was packed I was trying to get the attention of bartender who wasn't frequenting my end of the bar ever, she (short, dark hair) didn't appreciate my measures to get her attention and subsequently cut me off (every bartenders right, but man, does it sting) I voiced my displeasure and she invited another employee over to take my complaints.  

Hire a 3rd bartender if if you're going to be that busy.

Farewell Latin America, perhaps our 12th year together wasn't meant to be..
author: Jonas C.

description: Oh Latin American Club, you an you're margaritas did it again!  And by "it" I mean erased my memory for a few hours & rendered my useless the day after consumption.
author: George A.

description:
This is my favorite place in SF - super bar where u will ask a shot of whatever u like and get one size of 4. It's cheap and simple. You go there to drink - that what it's for. People who enjoy fancy drinks and decorations should go somewhere else and don't waste their time for being there and then yelping some complaints which this bar doesn't deserve at all.
This place (I repeat) is for wild drinking and if you are planning on one - welcome!
author: Mariya Delilah D.

description:
Strong. Pour. City.


Also, their Bloody Marys are almost as good as Zeitgeist's... just be sure to BYO straw!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Came to Latin American Club on May 27, 2012 at about 3 or 4 in the afternoon.  The HORRIBLE bartender behind the bar asked what we all would like to drink.  I wanted to know if they put Triple Sec in their margaritas because I am allergic (some places don't use it, and some will offer to replace it with something else)  and the ass behind the bar looked at me like I was crazy.  After explaining to him that I was allergic and that most places will replace it with something else he could see I was pretty annoyed with his rude responses.  After seeing the look of disgust on my face he was still incredible rude and said  "You ask crazy questions, you get crazy answers."  He was the biggest jerk I have ever had serve me at a bar.  Hopefully his boss reads this review and fires him. He definitely doesn't have people skills.  Needless to say, we all left the bar after his comments and we didn't order anything.  I wish I could rate this place a 0 but I guess a 1 will do.

I had heard that this place was an awesome bar and had some delicious drinks, but after that bartender, I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
My friend invited me out and I thought GREAT! Latin music sounds fun...but meh...it is just another bar. Hanging pinatas does not make you Latin...sigh. I felt a bit tricked by this bar or I guess my friend. 

Even the Mariachi was cut short...
author: Lidia Z.

description: had a little b-day get together here a few weeks ago and I loved this place! Pint sized margaritas made from ruby red grapefruit juice will have you not remembering much but hey isnt that the point! Definitely the spot for the truly cool, no pretense, dont want to get dressed up, hang out with old friends, make new friends get drunk and have a happy night kind of bar!
author: David H.

description:
Pale fruit, no straws.  

These drinks put the "ow" in powerful. One Latin cocktail is equivalent to two at a hotshot hotspot.  Learn it.  Or your inability to manage gravity may shatter both the glassware and your dignity.  

I like to sit outside under the big awning and celebrate the election nights of presidents I voted for (Yes, we did!), stare at Lucca and fantasize about ravioli, chat with the jovial regulars (one of whom is the Mr.) and sip my strawless margarita in the 22nd Street wind tunnel.  SLOWLY.
author: Rosie W.

description:
If you need or want a good cheap stiff drink then this is the place to go. I came here on a friend's recommendation and after reading the reviews about the stiff pours and the margaritas - why not!!!

The first time I went and ordered a margarita, my eyes bulged and my jaw dropped at how stiff the pour was. It was like 80% te-killya and the rest mixer. For as stiff of a pour it was, it tasted pretty darn good! Especially for only $8. For get about it. 

I always crack up when I ask for Patron or Don Julio and they are like, "you know that is $14." You go to any other bar in sf and on little weak ass shot of those tequilas cost the same amount of a 4-5 oz pour of their pint glass. 

4 stars only because it gets really packed in there sometimes and parking is definitely a biatch in the Mission.

This is my go to spot in the Mission. Latin American Club, please don't ever change!!!
author: Minh V.

description:
I came here with some SF friends on a Friday night on my last SF vaca. The bar was pretty crowded, but we managed to snag a table at some point. Definitely a laidback crowd. It could be my kind of place. 

I left Latin American Club feeling very warm and fuzzy and like I had received a good bang for the buck. It is quite possible that this is home to the strongest drinks in the universe. You've been warned.
author: Georgia K.

description:
Made some last minute plans on Saturday with some friends only to arrive at Beretta to find that they were at capacity and couldn't even let people in the front door.  I did a quick glance around the neighboring blocks seeing only what seemed to be seedy dive bars.  Now, I love a dive bar as much as the next person... but we were meeting some of our more "posh" friends and I was hesitant to commit to one of these locations. Appropriately, that was the moment I (being the graceful under pressure type) began to flip out (read: pout).

Thank god for my resourceful and calming bf.  He suggested The Latin America Club which was right around the corner and turned out to be just what I was looking for.  The kitschy interior had tons of charm and also plenty of places for our group of 4 to sit and talk.  Not all that common at 9 pm on a Saturday night in the mission.  The low lighting makes it a perfect spot for a pre or post-date drink as well. 

We only had one cocktail each but they were strong and tasty.  Next time, this will be my intended location.  Not the runner-up.
author: Meagan C.

description:
Kitchy bar that's inviting enough to the non-hipster crowd.

Margaritas are definitely the way to go, but..... My date and I each had 2 drinks (margs) for a casual night out and we both found ourselves at a wasted-level10 afterwards.  Make sure to eat before going near those drinks!
author: Gracie L.

description: Great bar to start the night. Cute little candles. Glad that it has tables, good for groups of friends. And you have to get the margaritas. Margaritas are no joke. Cash only!
author: Tanya P.

description: Cheap drinks..chill vibe..a place a girl can get into some serious trrrouble...and a brutal hangover...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Ahhh...the Pint of Margarita. 

It never fails to provide an evening of unpredictable excitement and intrigue. I try to cap it at one. 

Never go here in a snuggie, though, it's very packed, and therefore a tad warm.
author: Ima D.

description:
Winded down the night going to this place. Our drinks were strong! 

LOW LIGHTING, whoo hoooo!

I liked the pinatas on the ceiling (of course I would like something like that). Very busy, packed. We found a magical seat at the bar though. Score! Perfect for people watching/talking, yes! 

Laid-back, didn't seem pretentious. Which I appreciated.
author: Eva K.

description: Watch out people! I had 2 margaritas and my head was throbbing the next day! Pint sized generously endowed margaritas in a decently sized bar. Check it out if you want one good drink and the margarita is the way to go fosho.
author: Aristides N.

description:
Latin American Club - do not go here unless you plan on getting schwasty off of their margaritas. They are $8. They are served in pint glasses. They are at least 75% Tequila. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED. 

Past their tequilaritas, I didn't really understand the name. I guess there are pinatas hanging from the ceiling and all - but you can't even hit them. Lame.

It was uncomfortably packed on a Friday night and it took a little waiting to get in, but those tequilaritas were a game changer.
author: Caro D.

description:
About as Latin American as I am, which is to say not at all. Not sure how the name came about, but overall, I really like this bar.  It seems to have increased in popularity recently, which means that there are never any seats and it takes 15+ minutes to get a drink.  But once you get a drink, they are strong and the bartenders are personable.  

Good crowd of people which seems to skew slightly older (maybe late 20s or early 30s).  Also a good place to pick up foreign men, if that's your kind of thing!
author: Rebecca H.

description:
This place is not a club, so don't let the name confuse you. I went here couple weeks ago and the place is crowded. Though, you do have space in between when you  have a conversation with folks. People there are cool and laidback the time that I went. Noise level was loud but later on ...like any other place...it gets noisier, music gets cranked up a bit. The place is dark but you can still see everyone around you. 
I ordered a mojito and it was served in a big cup. Cost me $9. 

Before you leave the place, take notice above the door. They got some props like a nurse holding something. I'm not sure what was that about. Bar name and room setting has no connection to each other...
author: Eric E.

description: Awesome place ridiculously strong drinks and fun non-hipster-attitude from the bar staff...just don't ask for a straw.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Ok totally sold on this place. As the last night at of the tddoc I have to say this bar kicked my ass.There is a legendary margarita here that everyone was telling me was pretty potent. And they weren't lying. It was like 8  bucks for that thing in a tall glass which I believe contained mostly tequila. It was tasty. Sadly I made the amazing mistake of ordering 3 of those lovely beasts and then followed that up with up long island ... needless to say I walked out of the bar and fell straight into a passing by cab, but only after taking a small little nap on the little upper deck in the back of the bar.

I totally liked the vibe of this place. Random and not at the same time. There are pinatas that are all over but then there is a random gigantic gerbal/guinnea pig over in the corner. A  little tiny loft where there is a card table and chairs is raised a little bit above the rest of the bar where a few tables line the wall and the bar on the other. You can totally find a place here to chill and talk amongst friends. Bartender is a little meh and not too friendly however after thinking about the whole night in retro I think I might have forgot to pay for one drink and I feel real bad :( I accidently gave 2 fives thinking I had given 2 tens ... Oh well. She didn't say anything and maintained her very angry demeanor. I  just noticed as I looked in my wallet this morning.
author: Greg G.

description: they make this infamous "black-out margarita", which I found to be their signature drink, the margarita, and two of those will possibly make you black out.  The ambiance is divey and cool, it's a pretty young crowd, and the decor is quite interesting.  damn, those are some stiff drinks they serve. o_0
author: Terry K.

description:
this place is misguiding....
It is the least place where you would find a Latin American person, and it is NOT a club.
The location is great, sitting on the front is awesome for smokers.
It has been the same for the last ten years. 
I would only go there if a friend requests it, or if  Revolution Cafe is two crowded. Good for a night cap.
author: Taca A.

description: I don't think I was hipster enough for this place. Even the people come with their own body odor. Don't bother dressing up here b/c I was wearing a dress and stuck out like a sore thumb. The best part of this place was a 3/4 full glass of tequila in my margarita. We had Don Julio tequila for $14 with probably about 4-5 shots in it. Depending on who you get I guess you can get an almost full glass sometimes. You pretty much need one drink to last you the night. If you want to black out you can down 2 margaritas and possibly wake up next to someone you don't remember meeting and hope it isn't a dude with bad body odor.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
The drinks here are an uhhhmazingly good value.  As other reviewers have noted, $8 for a STRONG margarita that tastes pretty damn good!  I am usually wary of cheap tequila, so I started off with a $4 ($4! On a Friday night!) rum and coke, but after a taste of my friend's margarita I couldn't resist and the next drinks of the night were margaritas.

It does get crowded quickly and the space isn't too comfortable if you're not lucky to stake out a table.  If you do get a table, it's the perfect place for girlfriends to chat and catch up!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
This bar to me is pretty much a dime a dozen. I think that it's a decent bar to hang out with a handful of friends. I really don't have much else to say about this place other than it was just average at best. The decor was a little tacky with pinatas and other things hanging around the bar. 

Salude to mediocracy!
author: Darryl P.

description: The booziest of margaritas. Not too much seating and can get crowded, but worth it for the atmosphere and the drinks.
author: Sharon C.

description:
Good place. Very strong drinks. Gets crowded. I mean INSANELY crowded, like asses-to-elbows accidently knocking heads with people crowded. And that isn't my cup of tea.

But I like the place. The door guys are alright and staff just fine. It has a style about it that I can't really place.
author: Jay C.

description: These guys allow you to save face in front of your buddies by euphemistically referring to your normal evening pint glass filled with tequila as a "margarita". What's remarkable is that despite the fact that the glass is literally filled like 95% full of tequila, it's actually quite pleasant. They've also got a decent selection of beers available, which is useful for those nights where you simply insist on being able to walk home without assistance.
author: Madhu P.

description:
Any bar that has a giant mural of a Chiwawa on the wall has to be awesome. 

I've been here twice and both nights were great. Finished off the first evening with a round of car bombs. When the bartender said "No Guinness" I was very disappointed, but she substituted it with god knows what and everyone was pleased. On a side note, a car-bomb is a shot of Jamey topped off with Bailey's dropped into a half pint of Guinness. I won't deduct a star only because I've yet to receive this on the west-coast. Anyways, second night had some random/fun encounters and the crowd was pretty solid. Some people may consider it to be crowded but if you can get a beer and go to the bathroom in less then 10 minutes it's just good atmosphere.
author: Michael C.

description:
I came here on Alyssa G.'s birthday.  I think I had been here before, but it was a long time ago, or it was a different place that looked liked this, or it was this place but with a different name.

I'm quite proud of myself for actually reviewing a place in the 24th Street part of the Mission.  OK, this place is on 22nd, but I divide the bad old Mission into the 16th Street part and the 24th Street part.  I used to like the 16th Street part better, but then I've been to way more places there, so it's kind of unfair of me, seeing as I'm so set in my ways and often unwilling to try new places.

Back to Alyssa G.'s birthday.  I was surprised how empty it was when we came in.  It was early on a Saturday night, but we were able to snag a big table.  The place filled up quick, and I had fun helping Alyssa G.'s friend trying to find pseudo-hipsters like herself to hit on.

The space is fun but way too tweeny.  By that I mean that the place feels like it can't decide whether it's a bar or a restaurant.  I know it's not really a restaurant, but some bar-ish booths would be nice.

I felt all right being here because Alyssa G. is half Guatemalan and one-quarter Honduran (I think), so the birthday girl was 75 percent Latin American.  Most of this place's patrons were decidedly not Latin American, which I don't really mind but which is sort of strange and odd and typical in a San Francisco way.  Seriously, can we stop letting people from Boston into this city already?
author: John S.

description:
This is my go-to bar in the Mission.  They have great drinks at even better prices.  Their margaritas are the way to go!  For $8 you get a pint glass margarita that's about 85% tequila and still tastes amazing.  If margaritas aren't your thing, there are other great drinks to be had.  My friend Cathy Y. got herself a rum and coke (aka glass of rum, splash of coke) for $4.  Another highlight is the 21st Amendement Hell or High Watermelon beer they serve (in a can).  It gets fairly crowded on weekends but if you keep your eyes open you might be able to score a table.  On weeknights, its a great place for a date or catching up with a friend as it is much quieter.

To sum it up, come for the bargain drinks, stay for the awesome pinatas hanging from the ceiling!
author: Liz H.

description: This is a solid establishment, but the value has definitely gone down- the famous margaritas are now $12 (a 50% price increase from when I started coming here). Good but not great.
author: Jesse O.

description:
Where in the hell is the siding from my church house?  Oh, it's dangling from the ceiling of Latin America along with the pickup truck piñatas.  

Between the gerbil on acid, the random dog paintings on the walls and that they don't have straws makes this place pretty cool.  It doesn't strike me as a "party my balls off" type of bar.  Most people there were muscling down cocktails and having good conversations.  I like that they don't serve wine in wine glasses.  Nice touch.

Don't half step.  Don't ask for a straw with your cocktail.
author: Brendon D.

description: if you are 30 and over :don't go here. Your age will be felt and you will be gawked at like a dinosaur. Cramped as hell, can't hear a fucking thing, too cool for school vibe.I should have pushed my way through when I was still in my 20's, I always meant to but never did. Last night was a bummer
author: Lauren V.

description: Great place to have a margarita, trust me they are very strong. You only need one. Love the pinatas, atmosphere and festive decor. This is a great bar to start the night any day of the week. If you want to dance after having these margaritas, go to make out room across the street and salsa dance the night away.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Okay, I've been here twice now.* Always with great company, but even so, in an ideal world I'd rather not have to go back to Latin American Club. They're cash only. Lame. The margaritas that they're allegedly famous for are WAAAY too strong and, well, nasty. In my oh-so-humble opinion. 

My biggest issue, however, is absolutely the decor. It's dark, it's dingy, and it's full of the creepiest pinatas you've ever seen, plus these awful monster/mannequin things and the occasional taxidermist's masterpiece of some unidentifiable, unnatural-looking small animal. Oh, and there's a giant rat thing either painted on the wall, or it's a cutout. I can't remember exactly. But there's definitely a giant rat. 

Seriously, this is the stuff of nightmares. It's upsetting just to think about it. I'd say I'm sorry I don't have pictures to show you, but quite frankly I'm kind of glad that I don't. *shivers*

*It's kind of not fair to give them a 2 star rating, it should probably be 3 at least, and for some people the freakish pinatas/awful margaritas might be a draw. But, as with all Yelp reviews, this is purely my subjective opinion of the place, and really says more about me than the bar itself. Not a fan of severed heads with X eyes hanging from the ceiling. Especially ones that, in theory, you're supposed to crack open with a baseball bat, and then wrestle small children to the ground in order to collect and then eat the contents of said severed head. No thank you.
author: Jessica R.

description:
If you want to get absolutely wrecked on cheap tequila, go for that margarita. I will say, though, that I went there with three friends, each of us got ONE margarita, and if there wasn't roofie or some other unconsciousness-aid in there, I would be damn surprised. My friends wound up leaving the bar, but were so messed up that they thought I was with them. When I ran out to find them, my phone was stolen.

Plus, it's crowded and though the patrons were plenty friendly, the bartenders were not. If you are into being trashed unconscious, go for it. I'd rather stick on the side of safety, though.
author: Amelie P.

description: Simply my favorite watering hole for many years. The maragarita is dangerously strong but delicious! No pretentious. Just a nice place to hang out with friends. Better to get there early before it gets too crowded.
author: Chris W.

description: beware or be awesome, the margaritas here come in pint glasses and they are serious business. very well balanced and VERY STRONG! the atmosphere is relaxed, and the bartenders are great. great for a date or the last stop during daytime drinking.
author: Megan L.

description: You go to Latin American Club for the margaritas. And by margarita I mean "glass of tequila with a splash of margarita mix for color." BE CAREFUL. These things don't sneak up on you so much as they kick you in the teeth -- yet they manage to be more palatable than a glass of tequila. I don't know how they do that... but know what you're getting into. This place is a staple in every Mission bar crawl I've been on.
author: Adam D.

description: I absolutely love this place to begin (and sometimes end) a night. You can get drunk for $24 with two margs in a quirky, mellow atmosphere surrounded by beards and tattoos. If you go on the early side, you can get a spot at the bar which is great. Otherwise, standing can get pretty crowded but the atmosphere is fun regardless. Also, it's cash-only but there's an ATM inside.
author: Julia T.

description: You want a strong Margarita? Go to the Latin American Club. Like pinatas? There are a slew of them hanging overhead. This was a first stop one Friday night, and although already packed we were lucky enough to snag a table. Not only do the bartenders pour a good stiff margarita they are also speedy- I felt like I blinked and 7 pint glasses full of agave-based liquid were on their way to our table. Now whenever I think Margarita I will also have Latin American Club on my mind.
author: Shannon H.

description:
I'm giving this 3 stars because the first time I went there, I enjoyed it. Friends and I sat out in the front, people watched, enjoyed our drinks and the decor inside, no problem.

Then I went there last week after work...

My friend suggested that we try the margarita. I never tried their margarita and heard it was strong, so I was like "Cool."

Worst Margarita ever.

I watched the bartender mix the drinks. Nothing was unusual about her mixing, but DAMN the drink tasted like it was all tequila and bad tequila at that. We drank it and it eventually got better, but that was probably the effects of the liquor. 

Whateva. I only had one drink that night, and ended up with a hangover. 

Definitely stick with any other drink BUT the margarita.
author: Erica S.

description:
Latin Americans, myself included, like their drinks strong and their memorabilia creepy - deal with it, or don't go to a place called Latin American Club (duh).

I had some sort of delish Watermelon beer, talked about the cultural relevance of piñatas with some cute Cal PhD's from Argentina, and generally enjoyed myself immensely. The usual crowds + noise + impossibility to conjure a drink are entirely cancelled out by the fun vibe :)
author: Andrea W.

description:
Want to go from Good Time Charlie to Blackout Betty as fast as you can say "margarita?" This is your spot. 

I think someone said it best when they said the decor in this joint is like "a thrift store threw up"...well drink enough of those margaritas and that "throw up" line will foreshadow the way your night might end. 

Stout drinks aside, it's a fun little spot that is just wacky, tacky and dark enough to suck you into embarassingly emotional conversations with coworkers, and get you to down kamakazi shots like they were Shirley Temples. 

From what I remember, I like this place. But that being said, I'm always drunk enough to think going here (usually the third or fourth spot of the evening) is a good idea...and so drunk by the time I leave to wish I hadn't.
author: Laurel S.

description:
This is the only place in my life I have been to where there was a line for the guys bathroom and not the ladies. It felt awesome.

Yes, one marg will kill you here - you want to get $hitfaced? One large $7 marg and you are set.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Dear Latin American Club: I truly like you, but your hygiene is getting between us. I saw you in the afternoon a few weeks ago, and you were dusty, grimy, and generally disheveled. Just because you're a neighborhood dive bar doesn't mean that you can't tidy yourself up now and again. I think I'd like you more if you did. 
I'm just saying.....
-two
author: David L.

description: Cool little atmosphere, complete with pinatas hanging from the ceiling, and a little Mexican guy with a guitar serenading. A bar with some stools and pub tables along the walls. I was there around 8 on a Friday night. Get's crowded! Best known for great Margaritas so when here INVEST! :)
author: Charlene K.

description:
I'm still hung over from last night, and the truth is that I didn't even remember I had previously written a review for Latin American Club.  Seeing as how it was the massive, highly potent margarita that did me in last night and obscured my memory, I feel it only fair to update my review and grant an extra star to LAC.

Thanks for the (almost) memories.  This is a fun bar, lots of seating, friendly patrons who didn't mind when we sat down to share their table, and a generally convivial atmosphere.  I said I'd hit it again, and I did.  Wash, rinse, repeat.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Stopped by randomly on a Saturday night as a group of friends were wandering around the Mission and saw this crowd spilling out into the sidewalk.

The place was elbow-your-way-to-the-bar crowded, but the good mood and lively chatter of everyone there made that feel welcoming, rather than annoying.  The drinks were dirt-cheap, strong, and well mixed.  The bartenders had nearly endless patience and stamina for the people spilling over the bar.  

Will definitely be back.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
An impersonation of a typical pour at the Latin American Club, in real time...

- ahem -


Ice....
Ice....
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka
tonic
Vodka
Vodka
Vodka....
Lime.


Thank you, thank you very much.

(and thank YOU, bartender at Latin American Club!)
author: Ben H.

description:
I always manage to get shoved at least once when I'm at this bar, and I still like it and go back.  That should tell you something.

It's a pretty straightforward drinking hole that's always crowded.  I like the freaky mannequin display and the pinatas on the ceiling, and I always think someone needs to bring a long stick and knock some of those things down.  The art is usually gigantic and interesting - last night's display was a series of gargantuan black chihuahua paintings.  Why I find that oddly familiar and comforting, I have no idea.

We had kamikaze shots for 8, after having a lovely dinner at Garcon.  2 rounds.  And, for some reason, we were stuck on the topic of Meyers-Briggs tests.  Narcissistic fun at its best.

I got shoved by a guy making a beeline for the door and nearly spilled my drink down my front.  Again.  Yes, it was one of THOSE nights.  I never saw his face, just the back of his psychedelic shirt as he plowed through the crowd.

Why kamikaze shots?  Why the unnecessary roughness?  Why the giant chihuahuas?  Why no big pinata stick?  Why is this called "Latin American"?  I don't know.  

I just like it.

P.S. I am in NO WAY recommending the kamikaze shots.  I'm sure you have much better taste and judgement.  The bar is fun, though, so go for that.
author: Liz S.

description:
Do you know what a large gerbil sign has to do with Latin America?

I don't.  But I do know that it's pretty much the coolest bar decoration ever.  I mean, who DOESN'T want to get trashed and stare at a gerbil?  Well, unless it gives you flashbacks to some 90's frat hazing incident that's still costing you mucho bucks in therapy. 

The gerbil sign was probably the reason we came here.  Of course, the fact that I'm laying low from the Elbo Room after a "barfed on the bar, isn't she on Yelp?!" incident awhile back, didn't hurt either.

Reasonable* prices and a trendy** crowd.  

Nice place to chug a pint of anchor steam or sip your whiskey soda.  Unsure if you should keep drinking or switch to water?  Just look above the door:  the red lighted letters spell "S I N."  If you can read them, then you are too sober.

I highly suggest bringing a very cute boy to Latin American Club, not only to get wasted with while staring at the gerbil, but also to keep other vermin at bay.

*as in "5ish dollars for a drink" 
**as in "surprisingly high chance of bumping into a lawyer dbag who led you on months ago and never called you back." *cough*
author: Janney B.

description:
Strong-ass margaritas with salty rim. Check.
Cool-ass bartenders with salty tongue. Check.
Spotting Matt Gonzalez here hitting on young girls...Um, check?
author: Suzanne R.

description:
I think I was the only actual latin american in the place last night.  JT F thinks he's latin american sometimes but the only brown he is down with lies between two ass cheeks.  Bucky couldn't pass for an illegal day laborer even if you put bacon wrapped hot dog in his hands.

A divey bar in the mission that has lots anti-TGIF flair all over the place, formica chairs, pinatas, and even a velvet painting.  No bottled beer, only what they have on tap.  I was scared to try a mixed drink for fear of punking out after just one so I stuck with the Sierra Nevada Crystal Wheat draft.  It made for a good staging area before trying to hunt down the now elusive bacon cart man.

one extra star for the velvet painting, serious.
author: Luis M.

description:
The Latin American Club is in the middle of an identity crisis.  I don't know how many times I've driven by this bar and thought it was some sort of saloon.  The sign has a neon horseshoe on it, so one could only assume that horseshoe = saloon. But there are no gunslingers, player piano or short swingy doors.  I then come to find out that it's not a saloon but a Latin American Club.  So I start thinking that I'm going to have to be fending Latino men who want to salsa dance off with a stick, cuz I don't salsa.  I was working on the many different ways of saying "No thanks, I don't want to dance", when we approached the bar.  Only then do I enter the bar, realize it's not a club, and the only things I should be hitting with a stick are the dozens of piatas hanging from the ceiling.  But alas, no stick provided.

I think I could like this bar a lot.  The only problem I had with it was that we went on a Saturday night, and everyone else thought they could like this bar a lot too.  It was super crowded, and they have tables throughout the bar that take up valuable people standing space.  Other than a constant barrage of bootie bumps, some more welcome than others, the place had a cool feel to it.  I ordered my cocktail a minute too early though, because after I ordered it, everyone around me started ordering margaritas.  Strong but delicious, they are one of their specialties, joining the piatas in helping make this place Latin.  I think ill try this bar again, but mid-week, when I can join the Mission locals, and amateur hour hasn't hit just yet.
author: Lauren F.

description:
I'm getting concerned. A disturbing number of reviews I've written lately have been about drinking establishments. Or places I've eaten. While drunk. Or tattoo parlors.

My parents would not be proud. Thank god only one of them is alive and is only remotely internet savvy, therefore the likelihood of her stumbling on yelp is not great. 

And now I'm going to yelp about how excited I am that soon I will be living just steps away from the Latin American Club. Because it's dirty and divey and they have mannequins and cuckoo clocks and all other manner of weird and slightly disturbing trinkets on the wall, like something out of the A-bombed town in "The Hills Have Eyes." Or maybe it's more like, with the setting sun coming in through the ultra-dingy windows, hitting all the colorful vinyl chairs, I almost feel like I'm in that bar scene in "From Dusk 'Til Dawn," right before nightfall, when everyone turns into vampires...

Cool.

God, I love dive bars. And horror movies. 

God, I need help.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Alright, first things first. I liked this place and I will be coming back and while I am potentially risking spit in my drink for this, I can't not comment on this one retarded aspect of this place and that is....straws.

Apparently, LAC is too cool for the straw carrying school which honestly amuses me to no end. I happen to like straws for more than just their mixing value. I like to pick them up, bite them, twirl them and most of all, I like to wrap my lips around them and not have to touch the glass at a bar.. Why? Because, I don't know how well their glasses have been cleaned. I don't know who's hands have been on what, but gimme a straw and I don't care about any of that. Maybe it's stupid, maybe it's dumb, but it can't be any dumber than the attitude I got when I asked if I could have a straw....

"Um, we don't have straws."

Whatever chief.
author: Stephy S.

description:
I used to go to Latin American Club in the 90s when I lived in SF. After living in Brooklyn for over a decade, I returned for a nostalgic night out. Unfortunately a friend of mine who wasn't even drinking felt lightheaded and suddenly fell down. In response, I asked the bar mistress for a glass of water. She refused to look at me and when she finally did, was very rude and barked at me about whether my friend needed medical attention. When I said he didn't (after checking with him), that he just needed a glass of water, she said she had to finish pouring a drink for another customer and then threw me out of the bar! I tried to complain to another bar employee (an Alison Lincoln), who was initially sympathetic. Then when I tapped her shoulder to point out the woman who was rude to me, she literally screamed at me that I was being too intense and had leave.

I understand that a bar in a busy night has many drunks and annoying nuisances that they have to deal with. But this was not that situation. This was clearly a case of paranoid mishandling. It is sad to see a rather cool bar back in the day go down this path but this is essentially what has happened. I would in no way ever recommend going to this bar, on any day or night.
author: anne a.

description:
This bar's ambience is like...oh, I don't know, like a thrift store threw up. But that's not a bad thing; I love the decor. Especially the lit up letters that spell out "sin".

Nice place to chill and have a beer, Anchor for $4. Actually, a glass of beer should never be over $5. Being a couple blocks from home doesn't suck either. Must try that margarita I keep hearing about one day...

Oh, and apart from it's apparent history, there's really nothing explicitly Latin American about this place. Not that I noticed, anyway.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Margaritas served pint glasses? Stop it.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Latin American Club, huh?  Don't lump this place in with the Italian American Club or the Irish Cultural Center; you might be a little surprised when you arrive.  This is the neighborhood  bar with the neon horseshoe sign outside.  Why not just name it  "The Horseshoe?"  Oh yeah, the Marina got to it first.  Whatever.  

The crowd is fun and energetic; definitely a different hipster crowd than say...Casanova.  I get the feeling the crowd here wouldn't judge me for going to Fluid (see next review).  Or for liking Justin Timberlake.  Or for not voting for Nader.  No one here is trying to hard, and I love that.   While were on the subject of first impressions, try not to make a sad face when you fork over 6 bucks for a small-ass cocktail.  The bartenders at heavy-handed and the drinks pack some punch!

The decor is festive with the ceiling full of pinatas and the Dio de Los Muertos feel.  Also, I become an instant fan of places that offer outdoor seating.  LAC is not the kind of bar I would trek across the city for, but definitely hit it up when barhopping in the Mish.
author: Kerry D.

description:
Whoa!  They pour a strong drink at this place!  The night went something like this:

Round #1:
"Hi.  Could I get a Grey Goose and tonic and a Sapphire and tonic, please?"

Round #2:
"Hi.  Could I get a Grey Goo an ton and a Sapphire and ton, peez?"

Round #3:
"Hi.  Cuh getta Grgoo n ton un a Sapph n ton?"

Round #4:
"TAXI!"

Oy!  Who knew you could get so much vodka into such a little glass!?!?!?!
author: Jeff P.

description:
last night was my first experience with latin american club. i had only 1 margarita, made some bad decisions that i am unable to recall and wasn't able to go to work today.

cheers to an unexpected 3 day weekend.
author: sara m.

description: Anyone who would make a Hot Toddy and serve it in a pint glass in my books rule! Plus they have cider!! Love it here!!
author: Christina S.

description:
After not so great experience at Amnesia and Beauty Bar, this was a really good turn around. The place wasn't so packed and definitely chill, though we couldn't find place to sit. No biggie. 

One downer, they didn't have SoCo! I ended up getting Jack and Coke, which was STRONG! They ain't joking. I felt like I got my money worth though. 

I kept wanting to beat the shit out of the pinatas and imagining if they're filled with alcohol. Oh dear heaven!
author: Perry S.

description: Still a strong margarita but at nearly 2x the cost from 2 years ago...they allow dogs which is cool but it's typically too crowded to have a small pooch with anyway.
author: Lizzy R.

description:
They were not kidding when they said you only need 1-2 Margaritas and you'll be good for the night. I had a 1/2 a margarita and was done for the night ;)

The bar itself got super busy but it was a good international mix. They have tables so if you're smart go early and snag a spot for you and your friends. 

The bar is also cash only so don't forget to hit up the ATM before you go.
author: Summer C.

description:
Three people warned me about the drinks here and said to drink slowly. I didn't listen and now I'm at work and hung over and my heads hurts.... I think I need to hang out here more often.

Bartender service was a bit chilly but at least she's got a good pour!
author: Donna V.

description:
First of all, let me just say (since its apparent someone has to): You mean that big guy is named tiny? That is HIGH-larious! You see what they did there? He is huge. But they call him tiny. They flipped the script! Its like opposite's day! How novel, and droll. 

If you hang out in the Mission on a Friday or Saturday night, then I can almost guarantee you that you wouldn't traffic at bar that was full of Latinos. I know this, because those bars exist and all you incredulous Yelpers who are shocked... Shocked! That this bar isn't full of brown people should genuflect on the last time you interacted with a Latino that didn't involve buying something (no disrespect to those looking for Latin Love, but this ain't that bar either).

This bar has the best pour in the City, and some of the best bartenders. If you're the kind of person who wants the "realness" of the Mission on a weekend night, then go here, you'll be embraced in the familiar tropes of striped shirt, bleached hair and teeth. Which is Awesome! (I can't help thinking though, that Tonic or Bliss would really get you where you obviously need to go. Just sayin'!) But for the rest of us, we already know how to navigate a neighborhood that gets ambushed on the weekends (I have sympathy for North Beach now). 

Besides it's probably an empirical fact. If you don't like the Latin, you live on the other side of the Caldecott Tunnel. 

Don't lie. 

I won't judge.

I'm just sayin' the Skylark is bangin' on Thursday and Friday.  Or the Elbo Room.

That's all. I'm here to help.
author: Olu J.

description:
Ok, here's the story behind the name: 

When the Latin American first opened in 1852 things were a little tense. The US had just annexed California at the end of the Mexican-American war and the "Californios" then living here found themselves in another country without having moved a single step. What's worse they were now being overrun by scraggly Americano miners overcome with gold lust. 

Then Governor, Herbert McDougall, thought it would be a good idea, as a gesture of goodwill and electoral harmony, to build a club where Latinos and Americanos could meet, drink, dance and get to know each other, all while putting the tough times of the late-1840s behind them. On March 4th, 1852 a ribbon cutting ceremony was held and the Latin American Club was opened. 

In attendance was the former governor of Mexican California, Jose Gutierrez Pico, who brought along, as a gift for the bar, 20 pinatas, many of which still survive today. Popular accounts of the day recorded that one pinata was smashed for every round of drinks from the new bar. This continued until drunken revelers became a greater threat to each other than to the colorful, candy-filled animals. 

Also in attendance were famed 19th-century sportsman William Chinchester, who introduced the fast-growing sport of horseshoes to San Francisco, by way of an exhibition game at the opening of the bar that March afternoon, and renowned painter of dogs, Lawrence Crestwith, who presented to the bar a painting of his prized chihuahua, Max.

The Latin American has been a meeting place for friends and artists of all cultures ever since. 

Ok, I may have made some (or all) of that up...

But, yes, I think this is a great bar as well. Who hasn't loved, lost or celebrated a birthday here? I've done all three... some more than once.
author: Nik S.

description:
Holy guacamole!  These margaritas are STROOOOOOOONNNG!!!!!

So, so strong that after sitting with the same pint glass of the good stuff, having only consumed maybe a quarter of it, I had to ask for it to be watered down....it just tasted tooooooo strong!

I failed the margarita challenge.

Sigh.
author: Melanie B.

description:
BEST STOUT I HAVE EVER HAD.

PERIOD.

Seriously - - it was full of chocolate and coffee flavor, but it was beer -  meaning it also had alcohol.

Latin Club has a big bar and a really retro feel to it, bordering on being divey - but still has a lot of character.  I rather liked it, and the music was also good.  We happened upon it because we'd had dinner at Esperpento (all of us), and Latin Bar was right across the street.

Twenty of my friends and I came in, and we lined up almost all of the tables and chairs to make ourselves comfortable.  A few got up to buy drinks for most and all commented on how strong their drinks were.

Excellent.
I noticed they had at least 5 or 6 beers on tap.
Excellent again.



Of the tap beers, I chose the stout.




Don't know the name, and don't know the price, but I know it was THE GREATEST STOUT THAT HAS EVER TOUCHED THESE LIPS.

After a weekend of nonstop wine drinking in Napa, I cannot begin to tell you how good this tasted!


Edited to add:  Found out the name by going back:  Old #38 Stout!  Yummmmm!!!
author: Grace K.

description:
Went there with a very good friend who insisted we go to her favorite pub. I was a little suspect at first. But, Im always suspect because I think I know everything.

I soooo do not know everything. BUt I think it. Whatever. That's for me and my therapist to hash out. 

ANYWAYS

Love this place. The inside deco -- ridiculous. It's like every cool piece of anything that you've ever seen in a thrift store threw up in this place. So much to look at and it's all cool as shit.

The bartenders: friendly. fast. courteous. They don't forget a face, a good tip, and they sure as fuck know how to pour a drink. They understand why people really go out == to take the edge off goddamn it. and they don't forget that it's about having fun either.

The patrons: awesome. Everyone in the place is so fucking nice. Doesn't matter who you are. I hung out with soome crazy lezbian biker chicks and they're man slave outside smoking camel lights and drinking bourbon. I felt like I was in a William S. Bourroughs novel.
